list.name: Changes
list.comment: Version 2 of Factor Captor. Now when the user selects a 'computer' opponent, the user also selects one of two difficulty levels. The difficulty level chosen by the user is passed to the ComputerPlayer constructor. The difficulty level determines the instance of the ComputerPlayer's name and number selection strategy. A difficulty level of "2" means that when it is the ComputerPlayer's turn to select a number on the board, it will always choose the number that results in the optimal scoring advantage for the ComputerPlayer. The function that determines that number currently runs in polynomial-time.

task.summary:
Added "Player" class with basic methods to get player's name, score, set score, and print score.
Main function now asks user how many players there are and creates an instance of each player (two users or one user and 'computer')

Basic gameplay functionality works for two human players. When a player selects a number on the gameboard, the program determines all of the factors of that number and checks which of those factors are still present on the game board. The opposing player is prompted to identify the factors that remain on the board. The program correctly notifies the user if they have correctly selected a factor.
Created abstract "Player" class. "HumanPlayer" and "ComputerPlayer" are concrete subclasses of the "Player" class. A player has a name and score, and a player can select a number and select a factor.

Renamed "Grid" class to "GameBoard". Added to main() in main. main() now creates an instance of the GameBoard class based on user input. main() also determines which player will go first and begins the game loop. The GameBoard methods, HumanPlayer methods and ComputerPlayer methods still need to be implemented.
Implemented select_number and select_factor methods in HumanPlayer class.

All classes implemented. Bugs: 1. Instances of GameBoard are not updating after a number is selected. When a number on the board is selected, it should be replaced with 'X'. 2. When an instance of HumanPlayer is selecting a factor, the list of remaining factors is not properly updating.
Version 1 of the game Factor Captor is fully implemented.
Added static HelperFunction continue_game() which requires the user to press 'return' in order to continue the game. The function also prints a blank line, making the program's output easier to read.

Version 2 of Factor Captor. Now when the user selects a 'computer' opponent, the user also selects one of two difficulty levels. The difficulty level chosen by the user is passed to the ComputerPlayer constructor. The difficulty level determines the instance of the ComputerPlayer's name and number selection strategy. A difficulty level of "2" means that when it is the ComputerPlayer's turn to select a number on the board, it will always choose the number that results in the optimal scoring advantage for the ComputerPlayer. The function that determines that number currently runs in polynomial-time.

MESSAGE.value:
Added "Player" class with basic methods to get player's name, score, set score, and print score.
Main function now asks user how many players there are and creates an instance of each player (two users or one user and 'computer')

Basic gameplay functionality works for two human players. When a player selects a number on the gameboard, the program determines all of the factors of that number and checks which of those factors are still present on the game board. The opposing player is prompted to identify the factors that remain on the board. The program correctly notifies the user if they have correctly selected a factor.
Created abstract "Player" class. "HumanPlayer" and "ComputerPlayer" are concrete subclasses of the "Player" class. A player has a name and score, and a player can select a number and select a factor.

Renamed "Grid" class to "GameBoard". Added to main() in main. main() now creates an instance of the GameBoard class based on user input. main() also determines which player will go first and begins the game loop. The GameBoard methods, HumanPlayer methods and ComputerPlayer methods still need to be implemented.
Implemented select_number and select_factor methods in HumanPlayer class.

All classes implemented. Bugs: 1. Instances of GameBoard are not updating after a number is selected. When a number on the board is selected, it should be replaced with 'X'. 2. When an instance of HumanPlayer is selecting a factor, the list of remaining factors is not properly updating.
Version 1 of the game Factor Captor is fully implemented.
Added static HelperFunction continue_game() which requires the user to press 'return' in order to continue the game. The function also prints a blank line, making the program's output easier to read.

Version 2 of Factor Captor. Now when the user selects a 'computer' opponent, the user also selects one of two difficulty levels. The difficulty level chosen by the user is passed to the ComputerPlayer constructor. The difficulty level determines the instance of the ComputerPlayer's name and number selection strategy. A difficulty level of "2" means that when it is the ComputerPlayer's turn to select a number on the board, it will always choose the number that results in the optimal scoring advantage for the ComputerPlayer. The function that determines that number currently runs in polynomial-time.

A difficulty level of "2" means that when it is the ComputerPlayer's turn to select a number on the board, it will always choose the number that results in the optimal scoring advantage for the ComputerPlayer.
